title: Philosophical Dialogue
description: Engaging in Socratic questioning and dialectical exchange

exercises.title: The Elenchus Method
exercises.instruction: Practice Socratic questioning by challenging assumptions in the given claim

questioningSequence.example: What exactly do you mean by 'belief' in this context?
Consider someone who believes it will rain tomorrow, and it does rain. Did they 'know' it would rain, or merely believe correctly?
If someone believes something true by accident—a lucky guess—would you call that knowledge?
So you're suggesting that knowledge requires something more than true belief—perhaps justification? But this seems to contradict your original definition.

usefulPhrases: What do you mean precisely when you say...?
How do you reconcile that with...?
If we follow that reasoning, wouldn't we have to conclude...?

exercises.title: Constructing Thought Experiments
exercises.instruction: Present and analyze the following thought experiment orally

experiment.name: The Experience Machine
experiment.description: Imagine a machine that could give you any experience you desired. While connected, you would believe the experiences were real. Would you plug in for life?
experiment.purpose: Tests whether we value only experiences or also reality and authenticity

discussionFramework: Present the scenario clearly and neutrally
Articulate the intuitive response the experiment is designed to elicit
Explore what the thought experiment reveals about our values
Acknowledge the limits of the experiment's probative force
exercises.modelOpening: I'd like to present a thought experiment devised by the philosopher Robert Nozick. Imagine, if you will, a machine capable of simulating any experience you might desire...

exercises.title: Steelmanning Opposing Views
exercises.instruction: Present the strongest version of a position you personally reject
exercises.position: Moral truths are objective and universal, not culturally relative
exercises.task: Even if you personally believe in moral relativism, construct and articulate the most compelling argument for moral objectivism
steelmanningPrinciples: Present the position more compellingly than its proponents might
Address the best arguments, not the weakest
Acknowledge genuine insights in the opposing view
Distinguish the strongest version from weaker variants
usefulPhrases: The most sophisticated version of this argument holds that...
While often caricatured as..., the position is better understood as...
Even skeptics must acknowledge that this view has explanatory power regarding...
The most formidable challenge this position poses to my own view is...

exercises.title: Reflecting on Discourse
exercises.instruction: Practice stepping back to comment on the nature and structure of a discussion
scenarios: The discussion has reached an impasse; both parties are talking past each other
A key term is being used in different senses by different participants
The conversation has drifted far from its original topic

diagnosing: I suspect we're operating with different definitions of...
It seems we may be addressing different questions here.
Our disagreement appears to be less substantive than terminological.
reframing: Perhaps we might approach this from a different angle.
Let's step back and clarify what we're actually disputing.
I wonder whether our disagreement dissolves if we distinguish between...
synthesizing: Despite our apparent disagreement, we both seem to accept that...
If I understand correctly, the crux of our difference lies in...
Perhaps there's a formulation that preserves the insights of both positions.

pronunciationFocus.note: Five syllables; stress on fourth syllable 'lo'
Stress on third syllable 'neu'; often mispronounced
